questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Understanding the principles upon which the Church's moral teachings rest is more important than solving particular moral problems, since:

choices.A: Human persons are not in control of their destiny, but are fated for salvation or damnation by God's will.
choices.B: Communicating moral truth effectively requires that we be able to explain why a given choice is good or bad.
choices.C: Morality is highly subjective, such that different people seldom agree on what is a good or fulfilling way to live

questions.explanation:
Communicating moral truth effectively requires that we be able to explain why a given choice is good or bad.
See FC, p. 4.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Moral theology is the branch of theology concerned principally and properly with:

choices.A: The possibility of revelation itself and revealed truths concerning God.
choices.B: The offering of the Church's public worship, especially the sacraments.
choices.C: The relationship between human actions and goodness, in light of faith.

questions.explanation:
The relationship between human actions and
goodness, in light of faith.
See FC, pp. 1-2.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: The statement, _______, exemplifies how revisionist authors who reject the legalism of classical moral theology still retain legalistic tendencies themselves.

choices.A: "No one can be expected to follow the rules barring the divorced and remarried from the sacraments."
choices.B: "Jesus never explicitly condemned homosexual acts; therefore, such acts are permissible for Christians."
choices.C: "Catholics are free to reject Church teaching against contraception, since it was not proposed infallibly."

questions.explanation: All of the above

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Moral theology enhances the insights of philosophical ethics by:

choices.A: Proposing its own true insights, which at times contradict the true insights of philosophy.
choices.B: Utilizing divine revelation to further clarify the dignity and destiny of the human person.
choices.C: Using empirical methods to neutrally describe the phenomena of human existence.

questions.explanation:
Utilizing divine revelation
to further clarify the dignity
and destiny of the human
person.
See FC, pp2, 10-11

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Theology differs from philosophical and sociological approaches to religious questions inasmuch as:

choices.A: Theology seeks to clarify faith propositions already believed as true, whereas other disciplines employ a methodological agnosticism.
choices.B: The other disciplines evaluate the truth of religious claims, whereas theology limits itself to describing self-constructed meaning.
choices.C: The conclusions of theology are empirically verifiable, while those of the other disciplines rest on ultimately unverifiable hypotheses.

questions.explanation:
Theology seeks to clarify
faith propositions already
believed as true, whereas
other disciplines employ a
methodological
agnosticism.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Reacting against negative tendencies in classical moral theology, some contemporary theologians fall into an opposite error by:

choices.A: Emphasizing fulfillment in heaven and according little importance to this world, except as a kind of testing ground.
choices.B: Evaluating moral choices mainly in terms of their tangible outcomes, while neglecting their deeper spiritual significance.
choices.C: Treating moral norms not as mere rules, but as truths about the human person, intrinsically deserving of our

questions.explanation:
Evaluating moral choices
mainly in terms of their
tangible outcomes, while
neglecting their deeper
spiritual significance.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
Legalistic tendencies ought to be expunged
from the Church's presentation of moral
norms because they:

choices.A: Suggest fulfillment in this life is oriented toward fulfillment in heaven, not radically opposed to it.
choices.B: Promote moral minimalism and a truncated view of Christian life, inordinately focused on externals.
choices.C:
Alienate those who are unable to keер
God's commandments, even with the
assistance of His grace.

questions.explanation:
Promote moral
minimalism and a truncated
view of Christian life,
inordinately focused on
externals.
Feedback
See FC, pp. 6-7.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
By the time of the Second Vatican Council
(1962-1965), Catholic moral theology stood in
need of renewal because:

choices.A:
Lacking a positive theology of
Christian life, many saw holiness as
being opposed to human fulfillment.
choices.B:
Moral theology had become detached
from its scriptural foundations and
focused inordinately on rules.
choices.C:
There existed widespread confusion
concerning the Church's teaching on
fundamental moral questions.

questions.explanation:
Options 1 and 2
See FC, pp. 4-10.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
Moral theology enhances the insights of
philosophical ethics by:

choices.A:
Using empirical methods to neutrally
describe the phenomena of human
existence.
choices.B:
Utilizing divine revelation to further
clarify the dignity and destiny of the
human person.
choices.C:
Proposing its own true insights, which
at times contradict the true insights of
philosophy.

questions.explanation:
Utilizing divine revelation
to further clarify the dignity
and destiny of the human
person.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
In contrast to a legalistic mentality, an
authentic approach to morality locates the
basis for moral norms in:

choices.A:
Their suitability for realizing human
goods, and thus for promoting integral
human fulfillment.
choices.B:
Conformity with the truth about the
human person, who is created in God's
image and likeness.
choices.C:
Social convention, which rewards
conformity and stigmatizes
independent thought as deviancy.

questions.explanation: Option 1 and Option 2

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
The renewal of moral theology called for by the Second Vatican Council (1962-1965) included
elements such as:

choices.A:
An increased emphasis on sacred scripture and on the Christian's participation in Christ's redemptive
work.
choices.B:
A decreased emphasis on prohibitions
and an increased emphasis on the
positive demands of Christian life.
choices.C:
A decreased emphasis on human
learning, especially the social sciences,
in favor of more biblical literalism.

questions.explanation: Option 1 and Option 2

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question:
Theology methodologically prioritizes divine
revelation over other domains of human
knowledge because:

choices.A:
The Christian scriptures are among the
oldest specimens of human wisdom in
literary form.
choices.B:
God, who reveals himself through
scripture and church teaching, neither
deceives nor is deceived.
choices.C:
Christianity espouses a premodern
worldview which fundamentally
contradicts the claims of science.

questions.explanation:
God, who reveals himself
through scripture and
church teaching, neither
deceives nor is deceived.
See First Vatican Council,
"Dei Filius;" FC, pp. 2-3.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: A difference between commitments and goals, in the sense the course readings use these terms, is that:

choices.A: Commitments and goals are merely different names for the same idea, namely an aspiration to realize some potentially fulfilling human good.
choices.B: Commitments are never realized definitively, whereas goals can be realized once and for all, without the need for further implementing choices.
choices.C: Commitments concern tangible goods, such as a career or a relationship; goals, on the other hand, can involve abstractions, like self-improvement.

questions.explanation:
Commitments are never
realized definitively, whereas
goals can be realized once
and for all, without the need
for further implementing
choices.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: Structures of sin can make it hard for people to see objective moral norms as good or practical. For Catholics, an appropriate response would be:

choices.A: To remain silent about such norms, since insisting on them would only frustrate and alienate those who are incapable of observing them.
choices.B: To proclaim these norms in ways suited to their hearers, urging them to do the good they are capable of despite the limitations they face.
choices.C: To use whatever means necessary, including physical force, to destroy those responsible for social inequality and institute a just society.

questions.explanation:
To proclaim these norms
in ways suited to their
hearers, urging them to do
the good they are capable of
despite the limitations they
face.
Feedback:
See FC, pp. 13-16 (especially
pp. 15-16).

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: To say morality is primarily a matter of internal choice and secondarily of external action means:

choices.A: One can sin by word or deed, but not by thought, since thoughts generate no tangible good or evil consequences.
choices.B: The consequences of our actions are less morally significant than what we say about ourselves when choosing them.
choices.C: The violation of moral norms can be excused in cases where doing so realizes a great good or avoids a great evil.

questions.explanation:
The consequences of our
actions are less morally
significant than what we say
about ourselves when
choosing them.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: Examples of social choices, or those which constitute communities and determine their character, include:

choices.A: The choice of voters to elect an autocrat and not to oppose his authoritarianism.
choices.B: The choice of a man and a woman to give and accept one another in marriage.
choices.C: The choice of an unbaptized adult to receive baptism into the Catholic Church.

questions.explanation: All of the above

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: Free choice is significant as a principle of moral value, since:

choices.A:
Moral norms are cultural artifacts,
whose form and binding force derive
from a society's common agreement.
choices.B:
Our duty to respect the free choices of
others entails that whatever is chosen
freely is per se morally good.
choices.C:
Moral norms attain binding force when
individuals inwardly assimilate them
and choose to live by them.

questions.explanation: None of the above

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question:
An example of a choice in its proper,
philosophical sense, could be the choice
between:

choices.A:
Studying for a theology test or for a
chemistry test, when both fall on the
same day.
choices.B:
Going to class or going to the
infirmary, when one is suffering from
dysmenorrhea.
choices.C:
Trying out for the Ateneo varsity skiing
team or for the La Salle varsity skiing

questions.explanation: Option 1 and Option 2

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question:
Free choices determine the one who chooses
in the sense that:

choices.A:
All choices can be explained by a
sufficient reason, such as a person's
genetics or his or her environment.
choices.B:
Choices change our relationship to
human goods, causing us to find some
more appealing than others.
choices.C:
The attempt to exercise freedom
establishes the precise conditions
whereby one meets his or her fate.

questions.explanation:
Choices change our
relationship to human
goods, causing us to find
some more appealing than
others.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question:
Sirach 15:11-20 is an important passage for
moral theology because it underscores the
idea that:

choices.A:
Sin is a positive reality, the existence
of which is against God's will and
beyond his power.
choices.B:
The essence of sin consists in the
external, material violation of a divine
commandment.
choices.C:
Sin is the result of a free choice,
imputable to the human moral subject
and not to God.

questions.explanation:
Sin is the result of a free
choice, imputable to the
human moral subject and
not to God.
Feedback:
See FC, p. 13.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question: If choices are abiding spiritual realities than external performances, then:

choices.A:
New choices are needed to reverse old
ones, meaning that the mere cessation
of bad deeds is not enough to gain
pardon.
choices.B:
It is impossible to change a choice
once it has been made, which entails
that at least some sins can never be
forgiven.
choices.C:
Choice is an illusion, since a person's
actions depend entirely on God's
sovereign decision to grant or withhold

questions.explanation:
New choices are needed to
reverse old ones, meaning
that the mere cessation of
bad deeds is not enough to
gain pardon.
Feedback:
See FC, pp. 20-21.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question:
Christian faith teaches that free choice is a
basis of human personal dignity in the sense
that:

choices.A:
Moral standards and notions of the
divine are human constructs resulting
from personal or social attempts to
find meaning in the cosmos.
choices.B:
Unlike other material creatures, God
has invested humans with freedom
and invited them to cooperate
responsibly in their own fulfillment.
choices.C:
It would signify a failure of divine love
if God, who desires the salvation of all,
permitted humans to freely choose
their own damnation.

questions.explanation:
Unlike other material
creatures, God has invested
humans with freedom and
invited them to cooperate
responsibly in their own
fulfillment.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.2 Free Choice and Self Determination (FC 2))
questions.question:
In the sense the course readings use the term,
a commitment is:

choices.A:
The integration of the self around the
goods one has chosen.
choices.B:
A strong feeling of suitability or
aptitude for a given career.
choices.C:
A life-organizing choice, implemented
through smaller choices.

questions.explanation:
A life-organizing choice,
implemented through
smaller choices.
See FC, pp. 21-24.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question:
After studying the writings of Marx and
Foucault in her philosophy classes, Bhebot no
longer believes in God, though she still goes to
Mass with her devout mother, who urges her
to receive Holy Communion in the hopes that
the grace of the sacrament will rekindle her
faith. Bhebot politely but firmly refuses.

choices.A: Does not sin, since insincerely receiving Holy Communion would violate the judgments of conscience she is already old enough to make.
choices.B: Sins, since God has placed her under her mother's authority and she must always obey her in all things - even if she commands her to sin.
choices.C: Sins, since the presence of Jesus Christ in the Eucharist is a truth accessible to unaided human reason - the false god she vainly worships.

questions.explanation:
Does not sin, since
insincerely receiving Holy
Communion would violate
the judgments of conscience
she is already old enough to
make
The erroneous conscience
always obliges, provided one
has striven honestly to
dispel the error before
coming to a decision; see
Fulfillment in Christ, pp.
30-32.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question:
In a Catholic perspective, a conscience which
is honestly mistaken about moral truth:

choices.A:
Should not be followed, since following
it entails the external performance of
materially sinful acts.
choices.B:
Should be followed, since not following
implies the acceptance of an action
believed to be wrong.
choices.C:
Need not be followed, since the only
truth one can ever know is the truth
one makes for oneself.

questions.explanation:
Should be followed, since
not following implies the
acceptance of an action
believed to be wrong.
See Fulfillment in Christ, pp.
30-32.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question: Catholics should form their consciences in accordance with Church teaching because:

choices.A: Faith teaches that Jesus Christ entrusted the sacred pastors with authority to teach in his name; thus, Church teachings are to be received, not as human doctrines, but as the word of God.
choices.B: Catholics have been socialized in the religious traditions of their parents and so cannot conceive of right or wrong apart from the categories proposed by the Church and its representatives.
choices.C: Especially regarding matters of politics and economics (though less so those of sexual morality), Church teaching is supported by empirical data and aligns with the conclusions social sciences.

questions.explanation:
Faith teaches that Jesus
Christ entrusted the sacred
pastors with authority to
teach in his name; thus,
Church teachings are to be
received, not as human
doctrines, but as the word of
God.
See Fulfillment in Christ, pp.
35-36; Second Vatican
Council, Constitution Dei
Verbum, para. 10.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question:
Conscience formation is necessary for various
reasons, including that:

choices.A:
Social sin and personal ambivalence
obscure the objective demands of
morality and many of the practical
possibilities for acting uprightly.
choices.B:
Society is continually progressing,
which requires us to correct or unlearn
many old ideas about morality for the
sake of equity and inclusion.
choices.C:
Without a nuanced view of morality,
many people will feel guilty for
violating Church teaching rather than
seeing their actions as reasonable.

questions.explanation:
Social sin and personal
ambivalence obscure the
objective demands of
morality and many of the
practical possibilities for
acting uprightly.
See Fulfillment in Christ, pp.
32-33.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question:
In a Catholic perspective, the fact that
conscience sometimes errs entails that:

choices.A:
The findings of the social sciences
offer the only sure basis for resolving
moral questions.
choices.B:
It is futile to ask whether one's actions
are upright, since no one can ever
really know this.
choices.C:
Moral truth is an historically and
socially conditioned construct without
an objective basis.

questions.explanation: None of the above

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.3. Conscience: Knowledge of Moral Truth)
questions.question: Conscience may be considered a form of divine revelation because

choices.A: Humans resemble God most evidently when they creatively constitute their own moral codes.
choices.B: Conscientious non-Christians often grasp intuitively the moral principles revealed in scripture.
choices.C: Humanity's collective awareness of moral truth subsists as a personal reality, which we call God.

questions.explanation:
Conscientious
non-Christians often grasp
intuitively the moral
princifples revealed in
scripture.
See Rom. 2:14-16.

questions.question: On the basis of a Catholic understanding of conscience, one would most likely say Raymark:

choices.A: Did not sin, since all religions are equally valid; thus, one can appeal to other faith traditions to legitimate doing what one's own forbids.
choices.B: Did not sin, since life is the most important human good, and the necessity of serving it relieves a person of any conflicting moral duties.
choices.C: Sinned, for although it is not objectively sinful to eat dinuguan, Raymark believed that it was, thus violating his conscience by eating it.

questions.explanation: The erroneous conscience always obliges, provided that one has made an honest effort to dispel the error before coming to a decision; see Fulfillment in Christ, pp. 30-32.

questions.question: Forming one's conscience responsibly tends to produce effects, such as:

choices.A: Greater desire to know and do what ingood, and a diminished sensitivity to the opinions of others.
choices.B: Greater spontaneity and consistency in doing good, and a diminished susceptibility to temptation.
choices.C: Lesser reliance on moral authorities and greater confidence in one's own emotions and intuitions.

questions.question: The superego, or the interiorized sense of right and wrong absorbed from authority figures, is not the same as conscience, since:

choices.A: The conscience is one's self-constructed moral code, while the superego is externally imposed, limiting rather than enhancing personal freedom.
choices.B: The superego does not necessarily conform to social standards, resulting in cases of antisocial behavior
choices.C: The superego has no essential connection to moral truth, often causing people to act neurotically, in ways which subvert their human fulfillment.

questions.question: A sensible bad which is an intelligible good is:

choices.A: Vomiting, when induced by the unknowing consumption of spoiled food.
choices.B: Lactic acidosis, when induced by cardiovascular exercise, such as jogging.
choices.C: Cardiac arrhythmia, when induced by consumption of methamphetamine,

questions.question: According to Grisez, basic human goods are "good" in the sense that:

choices.A: They are imbued with moral value, hence their realization is always and per se morally good.
choices.B: Social convention approves them as being desirable, and their contraries as bad or undesirable,
choices.C: Their realization tends to promote the fulfillment of human persons, making them desirable.

questions.question: As a basic human good, marriage may be classified as:

choices.A: Sensible, since marriage is desirable as a means to achieving psychological and physical pleasure
choices.B: Substantive, since it fulfills the natural capacity of men and women to conceive and rear children.
choices.C: Existential, since spouses give themselves freely to constitute a harmonious marital relationship.

questions.explanation: See FC, p. 56. Marriage begins with the exchange of consent and is invalid without it. Insofar as the making and resolute persistence in this choice fulfills humans as beings capable of making choice, marriage is an existential good.

questions.question: An example of a person who realizes substantive goods without realizing existential goods could be:

choices.A: A priest, terminally ill with stomach cancer, who perseveres in his pastoral charge although tormented by his perceived failures.
choices.B: A powerful businessman, handsome and in peak physical condition, who engages in lurid acts of sexual depravity and violence
choices.C: A former criminal who reforms his life, prospers in business, and forgives those who persecuted him instead of taking revenge.

questions.explanation: This is Patrick Bateman from American Psycho. Life, health, and bodily integrity are substantive goods. The acts of carnage in which he indulges prevent him from realizing the existential good of justice, while his concealing these acts is a kind of inauthenticity.

questions.question: Grisez argues that being a good person without qualification is primarily about realizing basic human goods, such as:

choices.A: Health, wealth, and education, since no higher goods can be attained without first realizing them
choices.B: Harmony in one's choices and relationships, since these bear most directly upon moral goodness.
choices.C: Political liberty, since social injustice and structural sin impede the realization of existential goods.

questions.question: Grisez uses the term basic human good to denote:

choices.A: The utility of a person's activity, which can be used to determine his or her value to society.
choices.B: Goods which perfect aspects of human nature, which are appealing in and for themselves.
choices.C: Air, food, water, sleep, shelter, and other physiological requisites for sustaining human life

questions.explanation: See FC, p. 54.

questions.question: The statement which best expresses the Catholic theological tradition's understanding of the relationship between good and bad is:

choices.A: "God exists, and God is good; therefore, the Devil exists as the embodiment of badness, since there can be no light without darkness."
choices.B: "Bad is not a thing and has no being of its own; thus, badness is like darkness, which we understand only with reference to light."
choices.C: "Good and bad complement one another and create harmony, just as we need darkness so we are not blinded by an excess of light."

questions.explanation: See FC, p. 50.

questions.question: The statement, ____, is a concrete example of the proper response to badness proposed by Grisez.

choices.A: "Even if our conscience accuses us of sin, we may always approach the sacraments confident that God will overlook any of our misdeeds."
choices.B: "Expecting public sinners to repent before receiving the sacraments is wrong because it is exclusionary and causes them mental anguish."
choices.C: "Because it is spiritually harmful to receive the Eucharist unworthily, those conscious of grave sin must go to confession before receiving."

questions.explanation: This is the way of redemption, which heals and reconciles sinners with a view to their salvation; see FC, p. 54. See Code of Canon Law, can. 916; cf. 1 Cor. 11:27-32.

questions.question: Those who promise to contribute certain deliverables for a group project, but through negligence and procrastination fail to deliver them, fail to realize the goods of:

choices.A: Skillful performance, since they have not worked to the best of their ability, but generated inferior outputs.
choices.B: Justice, since they assumed obligations to their groupmates which they failed to fulfill through free choices.
choices.C: Practical authenticity, since their judgments of conscience were not implemented through external action.

questions.question: If every agent acts in view of a real or apparent good, then morally evil choices:

choices.A: Can exist, since not every particular good we desire necessarily leads us to true fulfillment.
choices.B: Cannot exist, since divine grace prevents those who believe in Christ from committing sins.
choices.C: Can exist, to the extent that people renounce creativity and acquiesce to the will of others.

questions.explanation: See FC, pp. 50-51.

questions.question: In the "Trolley Problem," a runaway trolley will strike and kill five people unless it is diverted; however, if it is diverted, it will strike and kill one person who was not in danger until then. A proportionalist would likely say the morally correct thing to do in this scenario would be to:

choices.A: Intervene, since the death of one is an adverse side effect accepted as the cost of saving the five, which is the best that one can do in the situation.
choices.B: Do not intervene, since one is not involved in the situation until one acts; but any positive action would violate the moral norm prohibiting killing.
choices.C: Intervene, since the death of one can be willed as a means to avert the death of five, thereby realizing a greater good and avoiding a greater evil.

questions.explanation: Here, intervention is framed as murder, albeit justified as a means to achieving a good outcome. This is proportionalism. See FC, pp. 61-63; cf. pp. 73-74, regarding the deleterious effects of proportionalist reasoning on moral creativity.

questions.question: Some proportionalists propose goods can be compared rationally with reference to community standards, which transcend individual preference. A difficulty with this proposal is that:

choices.A: Morality is highly contextual, depending more on intuitions than abstract principles that cannot account for the complexity of concrete cases calling for a Christian response
choices.B: Morality depends upon the will of God, which he can change arbitrarily; thus, a standard upholding marital fidelity would become evil if ever God decided to command adultery.
choices.C: Every human society is tainted to some extent by the effects of sin, which distort its moral priorities and preclude facile invocations of its standards as guides to right conduct

questions.explanation: See FC,p. 70.

questions.question: Proportionalism seems plausible for various reasons, including that:

choices.A: In everyday life, people explain clearly good moral choices in terms of realizing a greater good or avoiding a greater evil.
choices.B: Its insistence on choosing the lesser evil where there are no good options seems to account for exceptions to moral norms.
choices.C: Human goods can be compared on the basis of personal preferences, but no rational standard exists for weighing them.

questions.question: The statement, _____, is an example of proportionalist reasoning in application.

choices.A: "While marital permanence is a fine ideal, it can and should be set aside when infidelity or neglect have destroyed marital communion, so the parties can try to find happiness anew."
choices.B: "In treating cases of ectopic pregnancy,it is better to cut out the embryo directly rather than remove the whole fallopian tube, since this will minimize damage to the mother's fertility'"
choices.C: "All else being equal, the consecrated state is superior to the married state as a form of Christian life, since it involves a more intentional, singlehearted pursuit of Christian perfection'"

questions.question: To say, as Grisez does, that basic human goods are incommensurable means that:

choices.A: Basic human goods of different categories cannot be ranked or compared with one another; i.e., there is no rational standard for privileging the good of life over that of truth.
choices.B: Instantiations of the same basic good cannot be ranked or compared with one another; i.e. there is no rational standard for privileging the good of Jhomar's life over Einjhel's.
choices.C: When deciding what to do, either the greater good or the lesser evil is always to be preferred; e.g.,killing one innocent man is morally right if it saves the lives of many people.

questions.question: Grisez critiques proportionalism for undermining the creativity which should characterize the moral life, by which he means:

choices.A: Proportionalists are unduly focused on universal moral norms, which they say must be observed always, everywhere, and by all; but moral standards are personal constructs, neither fixed nor objective in nature.
choices.B: Proportionalism argues that one should prefer the greater good or the lesser evil without explaining why this should be so; but no one is bound to always prefer what is best, and one can freely choose what is worst.
choices.C: The types of moral calculations involved in proportionalist analysis require the simplification of complex situations, promoting binary thinking and preoccupation with more easily quantified substantive goods.

questions.explanation: The types of moral calculations involved in proportionalist analysis require the simplification of complex situations, promoting binary thinking and preoccupation with more easily quantified substantive goods. See FC, pp. 72-74.

questions.question: Grisez argues proportionalism fails as an ethical theory because it rests on unrealistic assumptions, including that:

choices.A: The consequences of one’s choices can be foreknown and compared in their totality, which presupposes omniscience on the part of the moral agent,
choices.B: Moral rectitude requires that one's will be open to the realization of all goods in all persons, although the Bible approves of xenophobia and misogyny.
choices.C: Divine revelation and Catholic teaching, neither of which can be proven empirically, provide a reliable basis for evaluating the moral quality of choices.

questions.explanation: The consequences of one’s choices can be foreknown and compared in their totality, which presupposes omniscience on the part of the moral agent,. Feedback: See FC, pp. 67-70.

questions.question: Cases in which the first mode of responsibility ("Do not be deterred by felt inertia from acting for intelligible goods") is fulfilled could include

choices.A: [Joe: Don't forget to replace this filler text before you publish the self-check, lol]
choices.B: Setting about to study for one's core subjects, but ending up spending the time tidying one's room instead.
choices.C: Pouring oneself a cup of coffee and studying for one's major subjects instead of sleeping in on a Saturday

questions.explanation: Pouring oneself a cup of coffee and studying for one's major subjects instead of sleeping in on a Saturday

questions.question: Cases in which the sixth mode of responsibility ("Do not let emotions bearing upon empirical aspects of an intelligible good interfere with a more perfect sharing in that good") is violated could be:

choices.A: A bishop who moves a priest guilty of financial misconduct to another parish instead of disciplining him.
choices.B: A priest who hears a man's confession, but keeps this knowledge to himself and doesn't denounce him.
choices.C: A layman who hears allegations against his priest, but declines to condemn him until he knows the facts.

questions.explanation: A bishop who moves a priest guilty of financial misconduct to another parish instead of disciplining him.

questions.question: Cases in which the second mode of responsibility ("Do not be pressed by enthusiasm or impatience to act individualistically for intelligible goods") is violated could include:

choices.A: Carrying an elderly woman from a burning house instead of letting her walk out under her own power.
choices.B: Giving money to street dwellers instead of encouraging them to earn a decent living by working for it.
choices.C: Cutting a school-age child's food for her, so that she won't make a mess and will finish eating sooner.

questions.explanation: Cutting a school-age child's food for her, so that she won't make a mess and will finish eating sooner.

questions.question: As used by Grisez and Shaw, the term "modes of responsibility" refers to:

choices.A: Concrete behaviors in which a will compatible with integral human fulfillment is manifested.
choices.B: Ways of choosing or acting in accord with a will compatible with integral human fulfillment.
choices.C: A fundamental orientation toward goodness itself, of which good choices are symptomatic.

questions.explanation: Ways of choosing or acting in accord with a will compatible with integral human fulfillment.

questions.question: Cases in which the third mode of responsibility ("Do not choose to satisfy an emotional desire except pursuant to the attainment of a distinct intelligible good") is violated could include:

choices.A: Choosing not to eat meat on a Friday, although the current canon law permits it.
choices.B: Purchasing useless or unnecessary items because one has disposable income.
choices.C: Preparing one's estate for the event of one's death, even though one is healthy.

questions.explanation: Purchasing useless or unnecessary items because one has disposable income.

questions.question: Cases in which the seventh mode of responsibility ("Do not be moved by hostility to accept the destruction, damaging, or impeding of any intelligible good") is fulfilled could include:

choices.A: A homeowner who, seeing her neighbor's garbage strewn on the sidewalk in front of her home, picks it up and bags it.
choices.B: A bishop who requires the faithful attending a Latin Mass to present a signed permission slip as a condition for entry.
choices.C: A shopper who, angered by the slow speed of the checkout line, buys many small items and pays in small change.

questions.explanation: A homeowner who, seeing her neighbor's garbage strewn on the sidewalk in front of her home, picks it up and bags it.

questions.question: Cases in which the second mode of responsibility ("Do not be pressed by enthusiasm or impatience to act individualistically for intelligible goods") is fulfilled could include:

choices.A: An electrician who gives dangerous jobs to an unqualified apprentice, to minimize his own risk of injury.
choices.B: A dean's lister who agrees to help his classmates earn higher scores by doing their share of group work.
choices.C: A girl who shows her father how to adjust his phone's social media notifications instead of doing it for him.

questions.explanation: A girl who shows her father how to adjust his phone's social media notifications instead of doing it for him.

questions.question: Cases in which the fifth mode of responsibility ("Do not proceed with a preference for anyone, unless the preference is required by intelligible goods themselves") is fulfilled could include:

choices.A: Sending all one's children for youth sports, even though only one is interested in sports.
choices.B: Spending less time reading to a cognitively disabled child than her neurotypical sibling.
choices.C: Canceling a date with a friend when one realizes it falls on one's wedding anniversary.

questions.explanation: Canceling a date with a friend when one realizes it falls on one's wedding anniversary.

questions.question: Cases in which the first mode of responsibility ("Do not be deterred by felt inertia from acting for intelligible goods") is violated could include:

choices.A: Arriving late to Mass because one spent too much time nursing one's coffee instead of getting ready.
choices.B: Choosing not to take this self-check because one needs the time to study for one's major courses.
choices.C: Declining the offer of an eighth gin and tonic because one is already drunk to the point of vomiting.

questions.explanation: Arriving late to Mass because one spent too much time nursing one's coffee instead of getting ready.

questions.question: Cases in which the fourth mode of responsibility (“Do not choose to act in accord with an emotional aversion, unless necessary to avoid a distinct intelligible bad”) is violated could include:

choices.A: A woman who, finding a lump in her breast, consults an oncologist to rule out cancer
choices.B: A man who, having been electrocuted by an appliance’s faulty wiring, throws it away
choices.C: A picky eater, who refuses to eat fruits or vegetables because he dislikes the texture

questions.explanation: A picky eater, who refuses to eat fruits or vegetables because he dislikes the texture

questions.question: An example of a person who commits a sin of omission could include:

choices.A: A student who misses the deadline for submitting her thesis proposal because she could not decide on a topic.
choices.B: An accountant who incurs heavy penalties for his client because he did not keep up with changes to the tax code.
choices.C: A rebel who places a bomb in an army barrack without checking to see whether there are any soldiers present.

questions.explanation: Option 1 and Option 2

questions.question: An important difference between goals and commitments, in the sense Grisez uses these terms, is that:

choices.A: Goals can be achieved definitively, whereas commitments are open-ended and cannot be realized once and for all.
choices.B: Achieving goals requires greater creativity than realizing commitments, for which definite courses of action are needed.
choices.C: Goals are chosen freely, whereas commitments are imposed from without; e.g., by God, one's parents, one's teachers.

questions.explanation: Goals can be achieved definitively, whereas commitments are open-ended and cannot be realized once and for all.

questions.question: If marriage is seen as a commitment to pursue authentic human goods in relationship with one's spouse, then it follows that

choices.A: Divine revelation is not normative for the content of marriage, which is determined by each couple according to their own values.
choices.B: Although they must avoid certain things (e.g., adultery), couples must determine creatively the positive content of their marriage.
choices.C: Those whose marriages are emotionally or sexually unsatisfying are not bound by their marriage vows and may marry another

questions.explanation: Although they must avoid certain things (e.g., adultery), couples must determine creatively the positive content of their marriage.

questions.question: If faith is seen as a commitment to pursue authentic human goods in relationship with God, then it follows that:

choices.A: The process of sanctification is ongoing, requiring one continually to discern God's will and seek creative ways of serving Him.
choices.B: It is sufficient for our sanctification to avoid committing mortal sins and to fulfill all the obligations enjoined on us by the Church.
choices.C: Those who have discerned a vocation to marriage but who cannot find a suitable spouse are in danger of losing their salvation.

questions.explanation: The process of sanctification is ongoing, requiring one continually to discern God's will and seek creative ways of serving Him.

questions.question: An example of a side effect, accepted but not directly intended by an agent, could include diminished fertility in the case of:

choices.A: A woman who undergoes tubal ligation to avoid taking oral contraceptives.
choices.B: A woman who undergoes a hysterectomy to remove her cancerous uterus.
choices.C: A patient who undergoes orchiectomy as part of sex reassignment surgery.

questions.explanation: A woman who undergoes a hysterectomy to remove her cancerous uterus.

questions.question: An important implication of the fact that interests develop on the basis of experiences, knowledge, and relationships is that:

choices.A: One can be morally responsible for one's interests, to the extent that these depend on previous, freely taken choices.
choices.B: Discrete choices are not fully free or self-determining, since they are conditioned by all of a person's previous choices.
choices.C: Some choices follow necessarily from a person's inherent inclinations, and so do not determine the one taking them.

questions.explanation: One can be morally responsible for one's interests, to the extent that these depend on previous, freely taken choices.
